title: Theresa May apologises for failure to appoint a child abuse inquiry chair: Politics Live blog | Politics | The Guardian
summary: theresa may 's child abuse inquiry statement - summary .
theresa may apologises for failure to find an inquiry chair .
a scottish labour leadership election round-up .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: theresa may , the home secretary , has apologised to victims of child abuse for her failure to find a chair for the child abuse inquiry .

in a statement to mp , she also announced that survivors and mps would be consulted about her choice of a new chair , that the inquiry would start work next week anyway and that a liaison group was being set up to help survivors communicate with the panel and government .
she also said the wanless report into the missing geoffrey dickens child abuse dossier presented to the home office in the 1980s would be published next week .
that was partly because she did not want it to overshadow today 's announcement , she said .
but it was also partly because she was ordering a rewrite to make it clearer , she suggested .

but it is also the case that i have asked - and it is not just a formality for me to receive a report of that sort - i have actually given it consideration , i have asked some questions to ensure that the report and the work actually has addressed the terms of reference that were given .
labour has accused david cameron of damaging britain 's interests by conducting diplomacy by megaphone '' with the eu .

commenting on the row with germany over free movement of labour , yvette cooper , the shadow home secretary , said : david cameron is putting headlines for the rochester by election ahead of getting practical plans in place .
this 'diplomacy by megaphone ' is no way to carry out eu negotiations or get the best result for britain .
all we 've had is chaotic briefings to newspapers rather than proper reform proposals or negotiations - little wonder they ca n't get agreement .
we do need reform to free movement in europe .

labour has proposed changes to introduce longer transitional controls when new countries join the eu , stopping child benefit and child tax credits being paid to children living abroad , doubling the time before people would entitled to benefits , making it easier to deport eu criminals , stopping recruitment agencies who only advertise jobs abroad and doing more to prevent employers using cheap migrant labour to undercut local wages .

these are reforms that could be implemented straight away , but the government has spent more time building up hostility amongst key allies in europe than championing changes that would benefit the uk .
labour has dipped below 30 % in the polls for the first time since ed miliband became leader , a poll has shown .
as the press association reports , a survey for conservative peer lord ashcroft puts the party on 29 % , a fall of two points .
ukip has dropped two points to 16 % while the conservatives are down one point on 30 % , according to the polling .
it is the first major poll to put the party below 30 points since miliband took the helm in september 2010 .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: theresa may 's statement - my verdict
text: when something goes wrong , own up and apologise .
it 's a simple rule and , in most areas of life , it usually turns out to be the most advisable course of action .

politicians , of course , are normally hopeless at this , but they should n't be , because theresa may has just illustrated rather well how a large dose of contrition , with a drop of humility , can get you through what would otherwise be despatch box hell .
in so far as i 've seen journalists expressing a verdict , they 've been positive .

christopher hope ( @ christopherhope ) yet again theresa may gets the tone right in the house of commons over a potentially very difficult statement over historic child abuse sam macrory ( @ sammacrory ) given how awkward this situation looked on friday , theresa may is handling the loss of a 2nd inquiry chairman remarkably well .
even labour mps were reasonably restrained .
steve reed is about the only one i 've seen being unforgiving .
steve reed mp ( @ stevereedmp ) self justifying excuses from theresa may over her failure to get the child abuse inquiry going 4 months after being pressured to set it up how did may manage it ?
partly it was her willingness to issue an up-front apology , and the measured tone she adopted throughout .
her direct message '' to victims at the end helped ( see 4.38pm ) ; in the wrong hands it could have ended up sounding phoney , but may ensured that this came over as genuine .

and partly it was because may actually had some actual concessions to announce ( see 4.38pm ) ; a series of measures intended to assure victims that the inquiry will start soon , that they will be fully consulted over the appointment of the new chair , and that the process will be carried out in such a way as to make evidence giving as stress-free as possible .
that said , it was still not a particularly comfortable ordeal for may .
it is too early yet to know whether victims will be impressed .
( as i write a child abuse survivor is telling the pm programme that he is still sceptical . )
and , on one or two issues , may did sound distinctly shifty .

she could not confirm that there will be an oral statement when the wanless report is published last week and , as barry gardiner revealed with an excellent question ( see 4.51pm ) , she could not explain properly why home office officials were helping fiona woolf obscure the extent of her relationship with lord brittan .
labour 's jeremy corbyn says the inquiry could turn into a standing commission on abuse .
that might not be a bad thing , he says .
may says she does not want the inquiry to just carry on and on .
if that were to happen , there would be a danger its recommendations would lose impact .
but she does expect interim reports , she says .
may says she is having discussions with the department for education about changing sex educations guidance in the light of concerns about abuse .
labour 's kerry mccarthy says the police treated some abuse victims as though they just had a bad choice in boyfriends '' .
does may agree that abuse can take place even if someone is in a relationship ?
may agrees .
there is an age of consent , she says .
and , below that age of consent , people should be looking very carefully at the possibility of abuse .
labour 's barry gardiner says may said earlier that the home office became involved in drafting fiona woolf 's letter in the interests of transparency .
but , with each draft , the letter became less transparent .
will officials be interviewed to find out why ?
may says the letter that came to her was the letter that fiona woolf agreed .
michael mccann , the labour mp , asks if government-sanctioned abuse , such as the short , sharp shock '' tactics used in detention centres in the past , will be covered .
may says she wants the inquiry to look at all kinds of abuse .
stephen mccabe , the labour mp , asks if proper checks have been carried out on all members of the panel .
may says due diligence was carried out .
and the members have written letters to may about their background .
mark durkan , the sdlp mp , asks if former members of the intelligence services will be able to give evidence to the inquiries on an unfettered basis .
may says the protocol determining who intelligence evidence is given is still be drawn up .
john mann , the labour mp , says the commons is having a holiday next week .
will may make a statement to mps about the report ?
may says she will make the report available to mps .
as to whether there is a statement , mann will have to wait until the business is announced .
philip hollobone , a conservative , asks if other countries have tried anything similar .
may says some other countries have , like australia .
the panel will look to see what lessons can be learnt from elsewhere .
but she says she is not aware of any other inquiry with quite such a wide span .

documents.title: theresa may 's child abuse inquiry statement - summary
text: here is a summary of the key points from theresa may 's opening statement .
the full text is here .
may apologised for her failure to find a chair for the child abuse inquiry four months after it was announced .

almost four months after i announced my intention to establish a panel inquiry , it is obviously very disappointing that that we do not yet have a panel chairman and for that i want to tell survivors that i am sorry .
she said that lady butler-sloss and fiona woolf both had strong credentials '' to chair the inquiry .
but they decided they did not command the confidence of victims .
finding a new chair would not be easy , she went on .

to put it bluntly , mr speaker , it will not be straightforward to find a chairman who has both the expertise to do this hugely important work and has had no contact at all with an institution or an individual about whom people have concerns .
she made a personal appeal to victims , saying that she understood why they may have lost faith in the home office but urging them to help the panel uncover the truth .
i want to end my statement by issuing a direct message to the many survivors of child abuse and their representatives .
i know you have experienced terrible things .
i know we can not imagine what that must be like .
and i know - perhaps because of the identity of your abusers or the way you were treated when you needed help - many of you have lost trust in the authorities .
i know some of you have questioned the legitimacy of this process .
i know you are disappointed that the panel has no chairman .
i understand that .
i am listening .
and to you , i say this .
i am as determined as you are to get to the truth .
that is why i set up this inquiry .
we have a-once-in-a-generation opportunity to do something that is hugely important .
together , we can expose what has gone wrong in the past .
we can prevent it going wrong in the future .
we can make sure people who thought they were beyond the reach of the law face justice .
we can do everything possible to save vulnerable young children from the appalling abuse that you suffered and endured .
let us come together to make this process work and finally deliver justice for what you - and too many others - have suffered .
she said victims , mps and the home affairs committee would be consulted about her next choice for inquiry chair .
i myself will hold meetings with representatives of the survivors of child abuse , starting next week .

i have already had a number of discussions with the members of parliament who have campaigned for an inquiry into child abuse - [ john hemming , caroline lucas , tim loughton , zac goldsmith , simon danczuk , tessa munt and tom waton ] - and i will continue to have discussions with them .
i will also discuss the appointment of the new panel chairman with the shadow home secretary and the rt hon member for leicester east [ keith vaz ] .
and i have already agreed with the rt hon member for leicester east that the nominated panel chairman will attend a pre-confirmation hearing before the home affairs select committee .
she said she would set up a survivor liaison group to liaise with the panel and the government .
it would meet on a regular basis as long as the inquiry continues . ''
she said she was taking steps to make it easier for victims to give evidence to the panel .
i can also tell the house that the government is considering ways of trying to make the experience of giving evidence less traumatic for survivors .
the panel will therefore take evidence not just in public and private meetings but also remotely , with witnesses able to speak to panel members from their homes .

the secretariat to the inquiry is also in discussions with officials in the department of health and other organisations to make sure that counselling and support is available to survivors before and after they provide evidence to the inquiry .
she said the panel would start work next week .
in the meantime , the panel will go about its important work .
so i can tell the house that the panel will hold its first meeting on wednesday , 12 november , and will meet every wednesday thereafter until christmas .

the panel will organise other meetings that will discuss the different themes and issues covered by the inquiry and attendance for these meetings - for both panel members and expert witnesses - will be set accordingly .
in addition , the panel secretariat is planning two regional events that will be held before christmas and another four that will be held in the new year .
these regional events will provide an early opportunity for survivors to give their views about how the panel should go about its work .
she said she was not putting the inquiry on a statutory basis at this point , but that she would if the chair requested that .
she said she had rejected calls to narrow the inquiry 's terms of reference .
she said she would not extend it to cover scotland , northern ireland or the crown dependencies .
but she wanted it to learn the lessons from inquiries in those jurisdictions .

i will , however , discuss with the new panel chairman how we can make sure that the hart inquiry in northern ireland and the oldham inquiry in jersey feed in to the panel to make sure that no information - and no institutions or individuals with a case to answer - can fall through the cracks .
she said the wanless report , into what happened to the abuse dossier that the late mp geoffrey dickens gave the home office in the 1980s , would be published next week .
may says there are two reasons by the wanless report is not being published today .
first , she wants people to be able to study it separately from today 's statement .
and , second , she has asked for an assurance that it is addressing the terms of reference .
( that suggests that she has demanded some kind of rewrite . )

labour 's diane abbott asks what the panel will be able to do if the intelligence agencies refuse to supply information to the inquiry , or supply it in such a heavily redacted form as to make it useless .
may says she wants the agencies to supply information .
if the chair needs extra powers , he or she will be able to ask for the inquiry to be put on a statutory basis .
labour 's paul flynn says the way the fiona woolf letter was rewritten amounted to an attempt to mislead mps .
the final draft of the letter suggested that she and lord brittan were virtual strangers , whereas earlier drafts gave a different impression .
may says she does not accept this .
labour 's tom watson thanks may for putting survivors at the heart of this .
it was a very personal statement , and will be appreciated .
what will be done to ensure the panel can get information from the intelligence services ?
may says it is her intention that all government agencies , including the intelligence services , should provide information to the panel .
she is in the process of establishing a protocol that will enable this to happen .

simon danczuk , the labour mp , says the decision of home office civil servants to get involved in drafting fiona woolf 's letter showed the self-preservation '' instincts operating in the home office .
may says woolf wanted to be as transparent as possible .
that is why so much care was taken over the letter .
may says it is shocking that those who were abused often raised their voices , but were not listened to .
this is an appalling attitude .
and we still see it happening today , she says , as ann coffey 's report into child exploitation in greater manchester ( pdf ) revealed , may says .
keith vaz , the chair of the home affairs committee , welcomes may 's statement .
allowing the select committee to vet candidates may set a precedent for other inquiries , he says .
who will chair the panel when it meets without a chair ?
may says she could appoint an interim chair .
but there would have to be a discussion with the panel , she says .
jack straw , the labour former home secretary , says may should consider dominic grieve 's proposal for the home office to appoint a chair from abroad .
may says she did initially ask the home office to consider someone from abroad .
but abuse is a problem in other countries too , she says , suggesting that having a foreigner would not necessarily on its own be enough to satisfy survivors .
sir bill cash , the conservative , says that if may wants to turn the inquiry into a statutory one , it would have to start again from scratch .
would n't it be better to give it statutory powers from the beginning ?
may says her advice is different .
it could be converted into a statutory inquiry .
but the request would have to come from the chair , she says .
david blunkett , the former labour home secretary , praises may for the tone of her response .
what steps are being put in place to prepare for further revelations ?
would be be sensible to have a joint chair , so that two people can consider the lessons to be learnt , and the way institutions must change ?
may says that is an interesting suggestion .
another mp proposed that idea this morning .
but she says she wants the whole panel to contribute to the inquiry 's work .
may is responding to cooper .
she thanks her for the tone and approach she has taken .
she says the panel secretariat has started meetings with survivor groups .
there will be further meetings , she says .
she says she thinks it will be possible to find a chair for the inquiry .
that chair must be able to lead a team .
she says she was not aware of the drafting process in relation to fiona woolf 's letter .
her special advisers knew a letter was being drafted , but they did not know the details of how it was being drafted .
may says every mp must be appalled '' by the size and nature of these crimes .
theresa may parliament

documents.title: yvette cooper 's response
text: yvette cooper , the shadow home secretary , is responding .
she says she first called for an overarching inquiry two years ago .
she welcomes the changes may announced today , and her apology .
for too long children have been ignored , she says .
no institution should be complacent about how they might have failed in the past , or how they may be failing now .
cooper says she welcomes the fact that survivors are being given a greater role .
originally may said it was up to the chair to decide how they were involved .
she is glad may is now meeting survivors , and setting up a liaison group to ensure their voice is heard .
cooper says may should ignore those siren voices '' who say you can not find someone who is not close to those involved .
does may agree it was unwise of home office officials to become involved in redrafting fiona woolf 's letters .
were special advisers or ministers aware of that ?
and can may ensure this does not happen again ?
will there be a statement on the wanless report ?
cooper says labour will support may taking whatever action is necessary to get the inquiry back on track .
but may must not ignore the abuse happening today , and the weaknesses in the child protection regime .
this is a once in a lifetime opportunity .
it must not be lost , she says .
yvette cooper parliament
may ends with a direct statement to abuse survivors .
i know you have experienced terrible things , she says .
and i know many of you have lost trust in the authorities .
many of you have questioned the legitimacy of this process .
you are disappointed the panel has now chair .
but i am as determined as you to get to the bottom of this , she says .
together we can expose what went wrong in the past .
we can ensure people who thought they were beyond the reach of the law face justice , she says
may says more evidence about abuse has come out since the inquiry was announced .
mps will agree that they owe it to survivors to let the panel start its job as quickly as possible , she says .
may says the wanless report into what the home office did with the geoffrey dickens dossier about abuse allegations in the 1980s next week .
she wants the public to be able to scrutinise it properly , she says .
may says she will not limit the terms of reference of the inquiry .
it will not cover scotland , northern ireland or crown dependencies .
but it will not ignore the inquiries going on covering abuse in northern ireland and the channel islands , she says .
may says some people have called for the inquiry to be put on a statutory basis .
the panel will have the right to demand whatever papers it wants , she says .
but if the panel wants statutory powers , it will be put on a statutory basis .
may says she will be meeting survivors next week to discuss a new chair .
she has had discussions with mps , and will meet with yvette cooper , she says .
and she will allow the home affairs committee to hold pre-appointment hearings .
the panel will start holding meetings before christmas , she says .
and it is organising events .

documents.title: theresa may apologises for failure to find an inquiry chair
text: theresa may says mps will remember that she made a statement in july announcing the inquiry .
she did so because of the growing evidence of child abuse , and concern over the failure of institutions to protect children from this vile crime .
she set it up as a panel inquiry so that it would have expertise from more than one person .
she names the members of the panel in place .
and she says they are supported by counsel and an expert adviser .
they have a range of backrounds , and some have experienced abuse themselves .
they can establish the confidence of survivors , she says .
but on friday fiona woolf says she was resigning as chair , because she did not have the confidence of victims .
woolf , and lady butler-sloss , both had strong credentials to chair the inquiry .
but , for different reasons , they both decided they did not have the confidence of survivors .
may says she is disappointed not to have found a chair after four months .
for that , i want to bluntly tell survivors i 'm sorry .
may apologises for failure to appoint an inquiry chair after four months .
i 've just topped up the scottish labour leadership round-up at 2.59pm with two new items .
theresa may will be making her statement to the commons on the child abuse inquiry in about 15 minutes .

as home secretary , she is used to having to defend grotesque whitehall cock-ups - the home office generates them with commendable regularity - but even someone with her experience is going to have trouble explaining why she 's lost not just one child abuse inquiry chair , but two .
it should be a lively session .
here 's rowena mason 's story with the background .
and here 's how it starts .

the home secretary will promise to consult colleagues and victims groups about how to restore trust in the government 's troubled child abuse inquiry , but a senior labour backbencher warned against giving mps a veto over the new choice for chairman .
theresa may will give a statement to the commons after fiona woolf became the second senior legal figure to resign as chair owing to concerns about her connections to the westminster establishment .
the home secretary will also answer questions from mps on the inquiry , which has been branded chaotic by keith vaz , the labour chairman of the home affairs committee .

victims ' groups , who are calling for a tougher judge-led inquiry with more powers to compel witnesses to give evidence and wider terms of reference , have been frustrated about being shut out of the process .

documents.title: a rochester byelection round-up
text: and here is a rochester and strood byelection round-up .
nigel farage , the ukip leader , has said his party 's campaign in rochester is going incredibly well '' .
this is what he told bbc news .
never in life should anyone say something is in the bag .
our campaign is going incredibly well , we are up support from across the spectrum .
i am confident but not complacent .
according to the professionals , rochester was number 271 on ukip 's target list of seats , so a win for us there would be very significant .
would it mean more defectors ?

well what it would mean is there will be people sitting on the backbenches who will reason , given the makeup of their constituency , they probably will have a better bet on a ukip ticket than sitting with a conservative one .
he also said ukip could not find venues big enough for its meetings .

norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) nigel farage says no longer any venues big enough in # rochester for their public meetings cos of demand for tickets william hague , the leader of the commons , has been campaigning for the conservatives in rochester .
medway messenger ( @ medwaymessenger ) @ williamjhague and @ twitterid have popped into our office # rsbyelection voters have been told they have got until tomorrow to register to vote .
chris irvine ( @ cgi247 ) remember remember the 4th of november is last chance to register to vote in rochester & strood by-election .
help us make history again # ukip

documents.title: a scottish labour leadership election round-up
text: here 's a scottish labour leadership election round-up .
the scottish labour party has published the names of msps and mps nominating rival candidates .
jim murphy has the most nominations for the leadership , and kezia dugdale for the deputy leadership .

holyrood magazine ( @ holyrooddaily ) boyack has received 10 nominations for labour leader , findlay 11 and murphy 27 severin carrell ( @ severincarrell ) based on latest @ twitterid leaders race nominations , we 're looking at @ twitterid and @ twitterid as new team murphy has signalled that he is opposed to devolving 100 % of control of income tax to holyrood .
this is from the herald 's story .
one of mr murphy 's main rivals for the scottish labour leadership , msp neil findlay , has expressed his sympathy for the call for full income tax powers .

yesterday mr murphy said : one of the important things about a tax system - and we saw this in the financial crisis and crash of 2008 - is how across the four nations you have a tax system that supports one another , that spreads wealth around the united kingdom .

now , when scotland has voted so strongly - with over two million people voting no to stay in the united kingdom - it would n't make sense to give up voluntarily one of the united kingdom 's real strengths .
a devolved tax system , yes - but while retaining aspects of a uk system sharing and pooling and that solidarity that comes from being part of something bigger . ''
speaking on the john pienaar programme on the bbc , he said labour 's two-year ­devolution commission had come up with ambitious '' proposals .
and , in an apparent nod to mr findlay , he said that all three '' of the candidates in the race have decided not to rewrite two years of work '' .
lesley riddoch , the scotsman columnist , has said labour should choose sarah boyack at leader .
sarah boyack has an instinct for co-operation and consensus building and progressive ideas about energy , transport and the environment .
that 's what labour needs right now .
the chance to regroup , find its moral core , put clear bluer water between holyrood and westminster and heal a little before next year 's general election .
as blogger kate higgins puts it : scottish labour needs someone who can lead their own people by following the scottish people . ''
precisely .
a poll has suggested that having jim murphy as labour leader in scotland would not help the party compete with the snp .
the num has said it is backing neil findlay as scottish labour leader .

kevin lindsay ( @ kevlindsayaslef ) national union of mineworkers have confirmed that they are backing neil findlay to be the leader of the scottish labour party # votefindlay three other unions have also backed findlay .

holyrood magazine ( @ holyrooddaily ) unions unison , aslef and tssa have declared for findlay , while it is thought boyack has a good relationship with councillors henry mcleish , the former labour first minister , has said he wo n't endorse any candidate in the leadership election , but that the new leader must urgently address deep-seated problems '' within the party .

as the press association reports , mcleigh also called for a leader who will accept the party has drifted over the last seven to 10 years '' , and that with a bit of humility we say to scots , look we did get it wrong '' .
unite has published the findings of a poll showing its members want an msp to become labour leader in scotland .
when asked who should lead labour in scotland - an mp or msp - 78 % of the 5,000 members questioned said they wanted someone from holyrood to do the job .
pat rafferty , leader of the union , said :

iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , told the world at one earlier that there was a remarkable degree of agreement '' among eu states about the need to restrict immigrants access to benefits .
these are proposals that this government - myself particularly - has been putting forward .

so i 've been in discussion with a number of people , from my counterparts in germany , spain , even france , holland , denmark , i 've talked to all of them on a number of occasions over the last two-and-a-half years and they all pretty much agree that essentially the system 's gone wrong and that countries should be able to insist on some form of contribution for a period of time , it 's just that which has not been finally agreed .

so the question is really how do we do that in fact , even mrs merkel agreed with that categorically when she said the eu is not a social union and there can not be de facto immigration into other eu systems .
so she was robust about that and we are in agreement with her .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: number 10 has said david cameron remains committed to stopping free movement being an unqualified right '' in the eu despite germany insisting that the free movement of workers is non-negotiable '' .

but the prime minister 's spokeswoman also said that cameron has not yet decided exactly how he wants to achieve his goal , and there have been reports that his reform proposals will focus on limiting eu migrants ' access to benefits , not blocking their access to the uk per se .
conservatives like boris johnson and david davis have suggested that berlin is bluffing .
( see 9.39am and 10.28am . )
nigel farage , the ukip leader , told bbc news that this was not the case .
my experience of brussels politics is that the germans do n't bluff .

they are very straightforward , they really do say what they think and mrs merkel would rather britain left the european union than those treaties started to be un mr cameron will try and fiddle around at the edges .
what he will not be able to do is to change the basic principle that nearly half a billion people if they want can come to this country .
that is n't going to change .
but some conservatives have said that cameron and angela merkel , the german chancellor , could strike a deal over benefits .
this is what jesse norman told the daily politics .
what 's interesting is that germany takes a much tougher attitude towards its immigrants within the eu rules than we do so maybe there 's more scope for manoeuvre than people sometimes think .

the issue really is n't freedom of movement ; it 's about the abuse of freedom of movement - it 's about people coming over here who do n't have jobs and who are potentially just going to become a burden on the nhs .
and this is what damian green , a strong pro-european in conservative terms , told the bbc .
the germans themselves are very keen on reform to some of the immigration rules to stop people exploiting loopholes if they have a generous benefits system as we do .
so , there are things that we can do that would serve to reduce immigration that would be popular and acceptable in countries like germany .
open europe , a thinktank , has proposed stopping eu migrants claiming benefits for three years .
as the press association reports , migrants would have the right to public health care but the cost would be covered by their state with any shortfall made up through private health insurance .
under the plan , which could be achieved without treaty change , the children of an eu citizen would have a right to access childcare and primary and secondary education .
open europe research director stephen booth said : angela merkel has consistently made it clear that germany is very wary of un the fundamental principle of free movement within the european union .

however , germany and other national governments across the eu would be sympathetic to reforms to access to welfare that concretely address the inconsistencies and perverse incentives undermining public confidence in free movement - not just in the uk but across europe .
instead of making a big pledge on reducing the numbers of eu migrants through quotas or a cap , david cameron should seek a three year moratorium on eu migrants ' access to welfare .

these reforms would be far from simply symbolic , they would greatly increase the governments ' ability to target their welfare and employment policies at their own citizens and reduce eu citizens ' incentive to migrate for low-income jobs .
george osborne , the chancellor , has announced that manchester is to get its own directly elected mayor with powers over transport , housing , planning and policing .
as alexandra topping reports , devo manc '' is the latest initiative in the chancellor 's plan to create a northern powerhouse '' to rival london , with other cities expected to follow .

the plans would see the post of police and crime commissioner for greater manchester police - established by the coalition government - scrapped and replaced by the new elected mayor , while further powers would be devolved to the greater manchester combined authority ( gmca ) , including some control over business growth as well as health and social care budgets .

osborne has been criticised for sending millions of households annual tax statements that show the biggest chunk of their contribution going towards welfare , with trade unions saying describing it as political propaganda masquerading as neutral information '' .

lord barnett , the former cabinet minister who devised the system for allocating public spending to scotland , wales and northern ireland that came to be known as the barnett formula , has died aged 91 .
the living wage has been raised by 20p to £ 7.85 an hour .
and the rate for london has gone up from £ 8.80 to £ 9.15 .
all official records of mps ' expenses from the scandal-hit era before 2010 have now been destroyed by the commons authorities , it has emerged .

documents.title: number 10 lobby briefing - summary
text: 10 downing street stansall/afp/getty images here are the key points from the number 10 lobby briefing .
number 10 said david cameron was determined to stop free movement being an unqualified right '' in the eu .
cameron was responding to the concerns of the public , the prime minister 's spokeswoman said .

[ cameron ] recognises that the british public has got concerns about the impact eu migration is having on the uk and that he is going to address that as part of the renegotiation as he said [ in an article in the financial times in november ] , this is about realising that free movement should not be an unqualified right and returning it to a more sensible basis .
there was a problem and cameron was determined to fix this '' , the spokeswoman said .
when the founding fathers established the european union and introduced the principle of free movement , it was about labour and how you integrate the countries of the single market .

the mass migration that we have seen with new countries joining , the impact on countries like the uk , the free movement to claim benefit - these are areas that have evolved and need to be addressed .
downing street played down the significance of the latest warning from angela merkel .
the der spiegel story was just speculation about a discussion between the prime minister and chancellor merkel '' , the spokeswoman said .
she also said that it did not say anything new about merkel 's position .
if it has surprised you that chancellor merkel says that free movement is an important part of the eu , then none of you were listening to her press conference in downing street in march .
the spokeswoman said cameron had not yet decided what to propose .
there is speculation out there .
i think that reflects that no decisions have been taken .

asked about today 's times story , suggesting cameron will propose stopping eu migrants claiming benefits and tax credits for up to three years ( see 9.55am ) , the spokeswoman said this was speculation '' .
she confirmed that cameron will announce his plans before christmas .
cameron has not had a conversation with merkel recently , the spokeswoman revealed .
george osborne will try to secure a renegotiation of the £ 1.7bn extra payment that britain owes the eu at a meeting of eu finance ministers in brussels on friday .
the government is still determined not to pay the £ 1.7bn by 1 december , as expected , and downing street is hoping osborne will make progress towards a deal on friday .
theresa may will publish the wanless report into what happened to a dossier about child abuse allegations handed to the home office in the 1980s very shortly '' , the spokeswoman said .
may has been accused of delaying its publication .
cameron will not be in the commons this afternoon when may makes her statement about the botched child abuse inquiry .
at the number 10 lobby briefing the prime minister 's spokeswoman made it clear that david cameron is still determined to do something about immigration from the eu .
[ cameron ] recognises that the british public has got concerns about the impact eu migration is having on the uk and that he is going to address that as part of the renegotiation .
but , as for what cameron will proposed , we emerged none the wiser .
i 'll post a summary soon .
in the meantime , i see angela merkel 's spokesman has been clarifying germany 's position this morning .
gavin hewitt ( @ bbcgavinhewitt ) merkel 's spokesman says germany wants uk to stay in the eu but 'the general principle of freedom of movement in the eu is not negotiable . '
gavin hewitt ( @ bbcgavinhewitt ) more from merkel 's spokesman on uk : 'we , the german govt , want britain to be engaged and to have an active role in a strong eu . '
you can read all today 's guardian politics stories here .
and all the politics stories filed yesterday , including some in today 's paper , are here .
as for the rest of the papers , here 's the politicshome list of top 10 must-reads , and here 's the conservativehome round-up of all today 's political stories .
and here are three stories i found particularly interesting .
tristram hunt , the shadow education secrtary , tells the independent labour should not be worried about promoting family values .
labour must recognise the importance of family values to take on the conservatives over social mobility , a senior member of the shadow cabinet has said .

tristram hunt argued the party needed to shed its leftist qualms '' about appearing patronising when tackling dysfunctional families - saying labour could no longer justify staying silent on a moral '' issue .

it marks a significant shift for ed miliband 's party as it attempts to fight david cameron on family breakdown , usually one of the tories ' favourite policy areas , in the final months before next year 's general election .
speaking to the independent , the shadow education secretary said labour needed to get over its fear of the 'f ' word '' .

we 're talking to labour colleagues about shedding any vestige of fear about talking about the importance and significance of the family , and how important stable relationships and stable parenting environments are for children 's attainment .
we should n't let the right and the conservatives have that , '' he said .
julia unwin , chief executive of the joseph rowntree foundation and a leading anti-poverty campaign , has used an article in the times to criticise labour 's minimum wage policy .
ed miliband 's plan to raise the minimum wage to £ 8 could politicise and undermine the issue for future generations , the head of a leading poverty charity has said .
julia unwin , the chief executive of the joseph rowntree foundation , warned labour not to allow the minimum wage to be subject to political whim '' .

her comments echo remarks by jon cruddas , who heads labour 's policy review writing in the times today , ms unwin said : establishing the minimum wage was a long and hard-fought battle , which should not be subject to political whim .
it achieved support from employers and unions , as well as being based on evidence . ''

she added that mr miliband had undermined the carefully crafted '' approach to setting the national minimum wage , but had also ignored the evidence that living costs for low income households often far exceed the general rate of inflation '' .
boris johnson in the daily telegraph says the living wage is a deeply tory '' idea .

i know that there are some free-market diehards who will say that london wages should find their own level - just as they might rigidly defend a mauritius sweatshop that pays its female workers 62p per hour to make ed miliband and nick clegg their t-shirts , the ones that say this is what a feminist looks like '' .

these ideological purists should remember that it was winston churchill who first proposed such a measure in this country , when he said : it is a national evil that any class of his majesty 's subjects should receive less than a living wage in return for their utmost exertions . ''

and the policy is surely deeply tory in that it is rewarding those who work , those who make an effort - the people whose daily struggle is essential for allowing the wheels of the london economy to turn .
i 'm off to the number 10 lobby briefing now .
i 'll post again after 11.30am .
douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary , says the german government 's stance shows david cameron is losing influence and support in the eu .
these comments by a german government spokesperson reveal that david cameron is both losing influence and losing allies in europe .
his weakness within his own party means he now risks pushing britain towards exit from europe altogether .
the right road for britain is reform within europe , not exit from europe .
britain needs leadership on europe which puts jobs , investments and the national interest first .
it 's clear that is not what we are getting from david cameron .

documents.title: boris johnson says merkel is just staking out a negotiating position
text: boris johnson , the conservative mayor of london , also seems to be saying that david cameron should call angela merkel 's bluff .
this is what he told sky news .
i do n't think for one minute that germany would want britain to leave the eu .
i think it 's the last thing they want .
we are close allies in our vision for a free-trade europe , for reducing bureaucracy , for reducing the wastefulness , all that kind of thing .
they need us as a counterpoise to the french and the mediterranean economies and their way of doing things .

i think it 's absolutely unthinkable that germany would want us to leave so i think you 've got to regard this as the staking out of positions in advance of what will be a very tough but , i think , ultimately successful negotiation .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
boris johnson lipinski/pa
here 's some of the more interesting twitter comment i 've seen on angela merkel 's warning to david cameron .

from mats persson , director of the open europe thinktank mats persson ( @ matsjpersson ) # merkel 's # eu migration 'warning ' to cameron unsurprising - most notable thing is how german media now drive headlines in uk @ twitterid mats persson ( @ matsjpersson ) bad translation by uk media .
@ twitterid said merkel thinks # brexit `` möglich '' = possible , i.e .

she fears it from sir christopher meyer , the former uk ambassador to germany and to the us christopher meyer ( @ sirsocks ) it would be distressingly naive of no 10 if it had really believed merkel could formally disavow freedom of movement in the eu .
from roger helmer , the ukip mep roger helmer ( @ rogerhelmermep ) angela merkel fears that britain is `` nearing the point of no return '' with the eu .
we in ukip hope she 's right .
roger helmer ( @ rogerhelmermep ) there is something strikingly nostalgic about a german chancellor presenting a british prime minister with an ultimatum .
roger helmer ( @ rogerhelmermep ) angela merkel calls it `` the point of no return '' .
i call it escape velocity .
from douglas carswell , the ukip mp douglas carswell mp ( @ douglascarswell ) merkel comments reveal what a sham the pm 's bloomberg position is .
# smokeandmirrors from the labour mp mike gapes mike gapes mp ( @ mikegapes ) merkel reported remarks are restatement of longstanding german and collective eu view .
a la carte cameron special pleading will not work .
from the conservative mep daniel hannan daniel hannan ( @ danhannanmep ) you know what , frau merkel ?
if we left the eu , uk-german relations would improve immediately .
from alex thomson , the channel 4 news presenter alex thomson ( @ alextomo ) this does not sound like chancellor merkel , playing her hand that high and that open and why now ?
alex thomson ( @ alextomo ) so the question is - did angela merkel really say all that about happy to see the uk leave the eu ?
or are we all being spun by der spiegel ?
from philip collins , the times columnist philip collins ( @ pcollinstimes ) can anyone explain cameron 's eu strategy to me ?
asking for the impossible seems unfathomably stupid .
what cunning plan am i missing ?
from the former labour europe minister denis macshane denis macshane ( @ denismacshane ) merkel sd no change in free movement at eu council .
nothing new in spiegel story from the times columnist tim montgomerie tim montgomerie ( @ montie ) me for @ twitterid : why is cameron panicking on immigration ?
because he 's ( wrongly ) afraid of a no confidence vote
one problem angela merkel may be having in trying to decide whether or not she can support david cameron over eu reform is that no one actually knows yet what cameron is proposing .

various ideas have been floated in the media , including a cap on migration from the eu , but cameron is not planning to commit himself until he makes a speech on immigration , currently expected some time after the rochester and strood byelection ( 20 november ) and before christmas .
the latest proposal is in today 's times .
its splash ( paywall ) says cameron is considering a plan to stop eu migrants claiming benefits , including tax credits , for up to three years .
migrants from the european union would no longer have their wages subsidised through tax credits , under plans being considered in downing street .

no 10 is examining a further migrant benefit clampdown after a furious angela merkel forced a retreat on the imposition of quotas on eu arrivals no 10 is now being urged to embrace plans to block all benefits for eu migrants , including tax credits , until they have been in britain and paying tax for two or three years .
tax credits effectively boost take-home pay by reducing the worker 's income tax bill to near zero .
ending this subsidy would remove one of the incentives for eu migrants coming to britain .
tax credits for workers are paid to those with children earning up to about £ 18,000 or a single person earning up to £ 13,100 .
about £ 5 billion of britain 's £ 30 billion annual tax credit bill goes to foreign nationals , according to analysis by the migration advisory committee .

documents.title: david davis suggests cameron should call merkel 's bluff
text: david davis , the former europe minister and conservative eurosceptic , was on the today programme earlier talking about angela merkel 's warning to david cameron about eu reform .
davis suggested that cameron should be willing to call her bluff .
here are the main points .
davis said merkel was not as powerful as some people presume .
she could be made to change her mind , he said .
your description of merkel - she is important of course , leader of the biggest country in europe , but she is not the iron lady .
i mean this is the lady who only a few months ago abandoned us two weeks before the decision over appointing juncker as the president of the commission now , why was that ?
that was domestic politics pressurising her .
now , you would n't have expected margaret thatcher to do something like that but that is what merkel did .
they are all like that .
they all play to domestic politics .
he said germany was partly to blame for immigration being a problem in the uk .
we have got hundreds of thousands of people applying for national insurance numbers in this country .
now , that leads to countries like poland and romania , but then you get spain , italy , portugal , - why is that happening ?
it is happening because of the euro crisis .
why is the euro crisis happening in the way it is ?
because germany 's insistence in its own politics .
it gains from it , everybody else loses .
he said cameron should sack the minister saying his eu reforms should be german-compliant '' .
we should n't allow advisors to go about and say things like : 'oh we are devising merkel-compliant polices , ' i would fire that man , whoever it is , straight away .
i think the phrase german compliant '' first appeared in the sunday times .
yesterday it quoted an unnamed minister saying this ( paywall ) .
another minister said : the focus is on drawing up a german-compliant package of measures .
cameron needs to square merkel or we wo n't get anything .
we 've got to stretch the existing rules to their limits .
there is no right in the eu to stay somewhere if you ca n't support yourself after three months .
that will be part of the package , i have no doubt . ''
davis said cameron should have started his eu renegotiation already .

i argued over a year ago that we should be starting negotiations a lot earlier to get away from this having an infinite number of by-elections a general elections and so on , because it undermines it from both sides .
he said the eu free movement of labour rules had to change .
on this one it has got to be a change of the so-called free movement rule to take on board that sometimes one country has an average wage one eighth of another country .
and therefore if you do n't do something there is going to be a massive flood from one to the other and that is going to cause social problems and economic problems .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
david davis jackson/getty images

documents.title: lord barnett has died
text: lord barnett , the labour chief secretary to the treasury in the late 1970s who created the eponymous funding formula for scotland ( which he subsequently said should be abolished , has died .
this is from the press association 's report .
labour former cabinet minister lord barnett has died aged 91 , his party has said .
he was the treasury chief secretary in the 1970s who devised the system for allocating public spending to scotland , wales and northern ireland that came to be known as the barnett formula .
the formula has remained in place , despite lord barnett 's arguments that it was a temporary fix and ought to be reformed as it now produces unfair results .
labour leader in the lords baroness royall said : joel was an extraordinary individual .
as an mp , minister and colleague in the house of lords , to the very end he was diligently holding the government to account and doing his best to ensure the best for the people of this country . ''
lord barnett 's daughter erica said he died peacefully at home on saturday morning after a short illness .
she said he retained his interest in politics during his illness and the last words he spoke to me were about the european union budget '' .

the upsurge in interest in the barnett formula following the scottish referendum - and the vow '' by david cameron , ed miliband and nick clegg to retain the system - had provided a great boost '' to him , she said .

barnett said : the barnett formula thing during the scottish referendum was a great boost to him , because he was able to say what he had been saying for a long time to anybody who would listen , but this time people were listening .
he had the chance finally to tell people just why he thought it was not only unfair but undemocratic . ''
lord barnett nicholson/pa archive/press association ima
george osborne , the chancellor , was on the bbc breakfast sofa this morning .

he was there to promote an announcement about greater manchester getting its own directly-elected mayor , but he found himself having to respond to reports that angela merkel , the german chancellor , has warned that proposals being floated by david cameron to curb immigration from the eu would push the uk to the point of no return '' on the route to leaving the eu .

osborne responded by saying that the story was based on a background briefing , not direct comments from merkel , and that merkel 's concerns were about plans that have n't been confirmed by number 10 anyway .

first of all , you need to know that david cameron and the conservative party always puts britain 's national interest first and we will do what 's in the interest of this country and the interest of this country 's economy .
what we have today is a story which is based on speculation about what angela merkel might have said about something that david cameron might say in the future .
so i think it 's a little bit thin .

we have had good discussions with the germans , i was in berlin just a few days ago myself ; they understand the disquiet that is caused amongst british people when you have people coming from other parts of europe here to claim our benefits , who do n't necessarily have jobs to go to .
this is creating a huge pressure on public services and the british public want this addressed .
so we 're going to do this in a calm and rational way , but the british people want this addressed ; we 're employed by the british people and that 's what we 're going to do .
but he also confirmed that cameron would propose changes to the freedom of movement rules .
you 've got to wait to hear what david cameron 's got to say , i 'm not going to speak for him and speak for him and give his speech on this sofa today .
what we 're going to address is this question of how freedom of movement operates in the 21st century .

it was never envisaged that you would have such large numbers of people coming , people coming who do n't have job offers , people who move onto our benefit system - although we 've been able to tighten that up in recent months , but it 's still the case that they can do that .
i 'll be covering reaction to the merkel story in more detail this morning .
later we 've got theresa may , the home secretary , making a statement in the commons about the ill-fated child abuse inquiry , which is now searching for its third chair .
i 'll be covering that in detail .
here 's the agenda for the day .
11am : number 10 lobby briefing .
3.30pm : theresa may , the home secretary , makes a statement to the commons about the child abuse inquiry .
as usual , i will be also covering all the breaking political news from westminster , as well as bringing you the most interesting political comment and analysis from the web and from twitter .
i will post a summary at lunchtime , and another at the end of the day .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of all the day's political developments as they happen, including reaction to Angela Merkel's warning to David Cameron about EU reform and Theresa May's Commons statement about the child abuse inquiry.
